article.heading: History
article.paragraph: The Andhras trace their history to the vedic age. Andhra was mentioned in theSanskrit epicssuch asAitareya Brahmana(800BCE). According toAitareya Brahmanaof the Rig veda, Andhras left north India and settled in south India.cite webDance Dialects of Indiahttp://books.google.com/books?idRagini DeviMotilal Bansarsi Dass81-208-0674-32014-06-09cite webHistory of Andhra Pradeshhttp://www.aponline.gov.in/quick%20links/hist-cult/history.htmlAP Online[[Government of Andhra Pradesh]]22 July 2012cite webAncient and medieval history of Andhra Pradeshhttp://books.google.com/books?idP. Raghunadha RaoSterling Publishers, 1993iv2014-06-09

The roots of theTelugu languagehave been seen on inscriptions found near theGunturdistrict and from others dating to the rule of Renati Cholas in the fifth centuryCommon EraCE.cite newsAge of Telugu languagehttp://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/article1971071.ece31 July 2013[[The Hindu]]20 December 2007cite bookSalomonRichardIndian epigraphy : a guide to the study of inscriptions in Sanskrit, Prakrit, and the other Indo-Aryan languages1998Oxford University PressNew York0-19-509984-21061. publ.
article.heading: Early history
Satavahana empire
article.paragraph: The EarlySatavahanasruledCoastal AndhraAndhra. The puranas refer toSatavahanasasAndhra Bhrityas. ThePuranaslist 30 Andhra rulers. Many are known from their coins and inscriptions as well. Satavahanas madeAmaravathi village, Guntur districtAmaravatias their capital.cite bookHistory of the Andhrashttp://www.katragadda.com/articles/HistoryOfTheAndhras.pdfDurga PrasadP. G. PublishersChapter 22014-06-09cite bookA Journey Through India's Pasthttp://books.google.com/books?idChandra Mauli ManiNorthern Book Centre81-7211-194-0Chapter 92014-06-09

Simuka (c. 230207BCE)After becoming independent around 230BCE,Simuka, the founder of the dynasty, conquered the present-dayMaharashtraand parts ofMadhya Pradesh(includingMalwa). He was succeeded by his brotherKanha(or Krishna) (r. 207189BCE), who further extended his state to the present day Andhra Pradesh. Later, Simuka madeSrikakulamhis capital.

His successorSatakarniStakarn Iwas the sixth ruler of the Satavahana. He is said to have ruled for 56 years. TheMaurya EmpireMauryansextended their rule over Andhra in the fourth century BCE. With the fall of the Maurya Empire in the third centuryBCE, theSatavahana dynastySatavahanasbecame independent. After the decline of the Satavahanas in 220Common EraCE, theIkshvaku dynasty,Pallavas,Ananda Gotrikas,Rashtrakutas,Vishnukundinas,Eastern Chalukyas, andChola DynastyCholasruled the land.G. Durga Prasad, History of the Andhras up to 1565AD, P.G. Publishers, Guntur, p. 116
article.heading: Ikshvakus
article.paragraph: Andhra Ikshvakus(Telugu languageTelugu,Sanskrit) were one of the earliest recorded ruling dynasties of the Guntur-Krishna regions of Andhra Pradesh. They ruled the eastern Andhra country along theKrishna riverduring the later half of the second centuryCommon EraCE.Puranascalled Andhra IkshvakusShri Parvatiya Andhras.cite bookHistory of the Andhrashttp://www.katragadda.com/articles/HistoryOfTheAndhras.pdfDurga PrasadP. G. PublishersChapter 32014-06-09cite webhttp://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/article3027992.eceAndhra Ikshvaku inscriptionsThe HinduTheir capital was Vijayapuri (Nagarjunakonda). It is a strong common belief among some historians that Andhra Ikshvakus were related to the mythologicalIkshvaku DynastyIkshvakus, while some believe Andhra Ikshvakus seem to be a local tribe who adopted the title.Ancient India, A History Textbook for Class XI, Ram Sharan Sharma,National Council of Educational Research and Training, India , pp. 212

Archaeological evidence has suggested that the Andhra Ikshvakus immediately succeeded theSatavahanasin theKrishna rivervalley. Ikshvakus have left inscriptions atNagarjunakonda,Jaggayyapeta,Amaravathi village, Guntur districtAmaravatiandBhattiprolu.
article.heading: Pallavas
article.paragraph: During third centuryAD, there was utter political and military confusion in the coastal Andhra due to the invasion of the Abhiras and their allies on the last Ikshvaku remnants and the rise of the Brihatphalayanas, the Anandagotras and the Salankayanas on the other. Simha Varma of the Manchikallu stone inscription establishes the independent rule of the Pallavas in parts of the Krishna valley of Andhra Pradesh.

During the reign of Maharaja Sivaskanda Varma of the Mayidavolu, Hirahadagalli, the early Pallavas became dominant power in the first quarter of the fourth century AD Sivaskanda Varma was the first great ruler of the early Pallavas. He extended his dominions from theKrishna districtKrishnain the north to the southPenner RiverPennarin the south and to theBellary districtin the West. He performed theAswamedhaand other Vedic sacrifices.

Most of the Pallava Prakrit and Sanskrit charters from the southern Andhra country intimately connects them with the history of southern Andhra. The influence of the Pallavas was still felt by Andhra till it was swept by the Western Chalukyan invasion led by Pulakesin II in the first quarter of the seventh century AD. The Pallavas were not a recognized political power before the 2nd century AD. Pallavas were originally executive officers under the Satavahana kings.cite webAncient and medieval history of Andhra Pradeshhttp://books.google.com/books?idP. Raghunadha RaoSterling Publishers, 1993682014-06-09

article.paragraph: Since the fall of the Ikshvakus, the Vishnukundins were the first great dynasty, which held sway way over the entire Andhra country including Kalinga and parts of Telangana and played an important and imperial role in the history of Deccan during the fifth and sixth century AD.cite webAncient and medieval history of Andhra Pradesh and telanganahttp://books.google.com/books?idP. Raghunadha RaoSterling Publishers, 1993702014-06-09

They wereBrahminsand their name is derived from their symbol andgotraname, which stood forNandi (bull)Nandi(the bull ofShiva).cite bookhttp://books.google.com/books?idAncient Indian History and civilization By S. article.heading: Chola Dynasty
article.paragraph: TheChola dynastyruled Andhra during the period of 10101200. The Chola territories stretched from the islands of the Maldives in the south to as far north as the banks of the Godavari River in Andhra Pradesh.
article.heading: Reddy Dynasty
article.paragraph: TheReddy Kingdom(13251448 CE)cite bookPran Nath ChopraReligions and communities of Indiahttp://books.google.com/?id4 July 20111982Vision Books136cite bookMallampalli Somasekhara SarmaMallampalli SōmaśēkharaśarmaHistory of the Reddi kingdoms (circa. 1325 A.D. to circa 1448 A.D.)http://books.google.com/?id8 July 20111948Andhra Universitycite bookGovernment Of Madras StaffGovernment of MadrasGazetteer of the Nellore District: brought upto 1938http://books.google.com/books?id1 July 20111 January 2004Asian Educational Services978-81-206-1851-052was established in present-day coastal Andhra Pradesh by Prolaya Vema Reddi in the early fourteenth century. The region that was ruled by this dynasty spanned present day coastal andhra from Vishakapatnam in the north to Kanchipuram in the south. Prolaya Vema Reddi was part of the confederation of states that started a movement against the invadingTurkic peoplesTurkicMuslim armies of theDelhi Sultanatein 1323 CE and succeeded in repulsing them fromWarangal.The History of Andhras, Durga Prasad (http://igmlnet.uohyd.ernet.in:8000/gw_44_5/hi-res/hcu_images/G2.pdfTodayReddysis a social group or caste of India, predominantly inhabiting the states ofTelanganaand Andhra Pradesh.
article.heading: Vijayanagara Empire
article.paragraph: The Vijayanagara Empire was an empire originatedSouth India, in theDeccan Plateauregion in the early fourteenth century. It was established in 1336 byHarihara Raya Iand his brotherBukka Raya IofSangama Dynasty.By James Mansel Longworth page 204edited by J C morris page 261By Om Gupta, page 428-429The empire rose to prominence as a culmination of attempts by the southern powers to ward offIslamic invasions of IndiaIslamic invasionsby the end of the thirteenth century.Nilakanta Sastry (1955), p216Kamath (2001), p160It lasted until 1646 although its power declined after a major military defeat in 1565 to theDeccan sultanates. The empire is named after its capital city ofVijayanagara, whose ruins surround present dayHampi, now aWorld Heritage SiteinKarnataka,India.cite webMaster Plan for Hampi Local Planning Areahttp://www.bellary.nic.in/HMP/REPORT%20PDFs/CHAPTER-2.pdfThe writings of medieval European travelers such asDomingo Paes,Ferno NunesandNiccol Da Conti, and the literature in local languages provide crucial information about its history. Archaeological excavations at Vijayanagara have revealed the empire's power and wealth.The region ofRayalaseemain the present day Andhra Pradesh got its name from the rulers of this dynasty whose name generally ended withraya, meaning raya ruled region (seema).

The empire's legacy includes many monuments spread over South India, the best known of which is the group atHampi. The Vijayanagara emipre's time is considered as the golden era of South India in many aspects by historian be it prosperity, welfare, wealth, military might and nurturing of arts. The previous temple building traditions in South India came together in theVijayanagara Architecturestyle. The mingling of all faiths and vernaculars inspired architectural innovation ofHindutemple construction, first in the Deccan and later in theDravidian architectureDravidianidioms using the localgranite. Efficient administration and vigorous overseas trade brought new technologies such as water management systems for irrigation. The empire's patronage enabled fine arts and literature to reach new heights inKannada languageKannada,Telugu languageTelugu,Tamil languageTamilandSanskrit, whileCarnatic musicevolved into its current form. The Vijayanagara Empire created an epoch in South Indian history that transcended regionalism by promotingHinduismas a unifying factor.Historians such asP. B. Desai(History of Vijayanagar Empire, 1936),Henry Heras(The Aravidu Dynasty of Vijayanagara, 1927),B.A. Saletore(Social and Political Life in the Vijayanagara Empire, 1930), G.S. Gai (Archaeological Survey of India), William Coelho (The Hoysala Vamsa, 1955) and Kamath (Kamath 2001, pp. 157160)
article.heading: Modern history
article.paragraph: Inspired by their success, theVijayanagara Empire, one of the greatest empires in the history of Andhra Pradesh and India, was founded byHariharaandBukka, who served as treasury officers of the Kakatiyas of Warangal.Robert Sewell,A Forgotten Empire (Vijayanagar): A contribution to the history of India, Chapter 2Gutenberg.orgDead linkJune 2015In 1347Common EraCE, an independent Muslim state, theBahmani Sultanate, was established insouth IndiabyAla-ud-Din Bahman Shahin a revolt against the Delhi Sultanate. TheQutb Shahi dynastyheld sway over the Andhra country for about two hundred years from the early part of the sixteenth century to the end of the seventeenth century.Cite journalRichardsJ. F.The Hyderabad Karnatik, 1687–17071975[[Modern Asian Studies]]92241–26010.1017/S0026749X00004996

InColonial India,Northern Circarsbecame part of the BritishMadras Presidency. Eventually this region emerged as theCoastal Andhraregion. Later theNizamrulers of Hyderabad ceded five territories to the British which eventually emerged asRayalaseemaregion. The Nizams retained control of the interior provinces as theprincely stateofHyderabad StateHyderabad, acknowledging British rule in return for local autonomy. However,Komaram Bheem, a tribal leader, started his fight against the erstwhileAsaf Jahi Dynastyfor the liberation ofHyderabad State.cite newshttp://www.thehindu.com/2005/09/18/stories/2005091816590500.htmChennai, IndiaThe Hindu18 September 2005Tributes paid to Telangana martyrsMeanwhile, theFrench colonial empireFrenchoccupiedYanam (India)Yanam, in the Godavari delta, and (save for periods of British control) would hold it until 1954.In 1947 Vizianagaram was the largest Hindu Princely state in Andhra Pradesh.

Indian independence movementIndia became independentfrom the United Kingdom in 1947. The Nizam wanted to retain the independence of the Princely Hyderabad State from India, but the people of the region launched a movement to join the Indian Union. The state of Hyderabad was forcibly joined to the Republic of India withOperation Poloin 1948.cite newshttp://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,799076-2,00.htmlTimeHYDERABAD: The Holdout30 August 194820 May 2010http://web.archive.org/web/20100522212635/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,799076-2,00.html22 May 2010no

article.paragraph: see alsoAndhra StateVisalandhra MovementIn an effort to gain an independent state based on linguistic differences and to protect the interests of the Telugu-speaking people ofMadras State,Potti Sreeramulufasted until death in 1952. As Madras became a bone of contention, in 1949 a JVP committee report stated "Andhra Province could be formed provided the Andhras give up their claim on the city of Madras (now Chennai)". After Potti Sreeramulu's death, the Telugu-speaking areas, i.e.Andhra State, was carved out ofMadras Stateon 1nbspOctober 1953, withKurnoolas its capital city.cite webhttp://www.aponline.gov.in/quick%20links/hist-cult/history_post.html#EmergencePost-Independence Era, then and nowaponline.gov.in3 August 2013

article.heading: Geography

template.arg: List of districts of Andhra Pradesh

article.paragraph: Geographically, Andhra Pradesh is bestowed with two mighty river systems ofKrishna RiverKrishnaandGodavari riverGodavari. Its varied topography ranging from the hills ofEastern GhatsandNallamala HillsNallamallasto the shores ofBay of Bengalsupports varied ecotypes, rich diversity of flora and fauna. The state has two regionsCoastal AndhraandRayalaseema.cite webhttp://www.maharashtraweb.com/AndhraPradesh/AndhraPradeshgeography.htmAndhra Pradesh GeographyMaharashtraweb.com15 August 2010http://web.archive.org/web/20100929081617/http://maharashtraweb.com/AndhraPradesh/AndhraPradeshgeography.htm29 September 2010noThe plains to the east of Eastern Ghats form theEastern coastal plains. The coastal plains are for the most part of delta regions formed by theGodavari RiverGodavari,River KrishnaKrishna, andPenner RiverPennarivers. The Eastern Ghats are discontinuous and individual sections have local names. The Eastern Ghats are a major dividing line in the state's geography. The Kadapa Basincite webKadapa basinhttp://www.dghindia.org/10.aspxDirectorate General of Hydrocarbons6 June 2014formed by two arching branches of the Eastern Ghats is a mineral-rich area. The Ghats become more pronounced towards the south and extreme north of the coast. Most of the coastal plains are put to intense agricultural use. TheRayalaseemaregion has semi-arid conditions.Lambasingi(or Lammasingi), a village in the Chintapalli Mandal ofVisakhapatnam districtis situated at 1000 meters above the sea level. It is the only place in South India which has snowfall and is also nicknamed asKashmir of Andhra Pradesh. Throughout the year the temperature here ranges from 0 C to 10 C.cite newsGangulyNiveditaLambasingi set to become tourist hotspothttp://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Visakhapatnam/lambasingi-set-to-become-tourist-hotspot/article6416560.ece26 November 2014The Hindu17 September 2014Visakhapatnamcite newsLambasingi records 2º chttp://www.deccanchronicle.com/131216/news-current-affairs/article/lambasingi-records-2%C2%BA-c26 November 2014Deccan Chronicle16 December 2013Visakhapatnam
article.heading: Natural vegetation

template.arg: Natural vegetation and Wildlife of Andhra Pradesh

article.paragraph: Andhra Pradesh Forest Departmentdeals with protection, conservation and management offorests. The total forest cover of the state after the bifurcation is left with an area of 22,862 km2.cite webForests in AP facts.http://forest.ap.nic.in/About.htmAP Forest department6 June 2014The forest in the state can be broadly divided into four major biotic provinces.cite webNatural vegetation and wildlifehttp://forest.ap.nic.in/WLINDEX.htmAP Forest Department6 June 2014They are:

Eastern Ghatsregion is home to dense tropical forests, while the vegetation becomes sparse as the Ghats give way to the Deccan Plateau, where shrub vegetation is more common. These Ghats have rich biological diversity with a wide variety of plants, birds and lesser forms of animal life. The vegetation found in the state is largely of dry deciduous types with a mixture ofteak,Terminalia (plant)Terminalia,Dalbergia,Pterocarpus,Anogeissus, etc.The state possesses some rare and endemic plants likeCycas beddomei,Pterocarpus santalinus,Terminalia pallida,Syzygium alternifolium,Shorea talura,Shorea tumburgia,Psilotum nudum, etc.

The diversity of fauna includes tigers, panthers, hyenas, black bucks, cheetals, sambars, sea turtles and a number of birds and reptiles. The estuaries of river Godavari and Krishna support rich mangrove forests with fishing cats and otters as keystone species.
article.heading: Climate
article.paragraph: The climate of Andhra Pradesh varies considerably, depending on the geographical region. Monsoons play a major role in determining the climate of the state. Summers last from March to June. In the coastal plain, the summer temperatures are generally higher than the rest of the state, with temperature ranging between 20 C and 41 C.

July to September is the season for tropical rains in Andhra Pradesh. The state receives heavy rainfall from the southwest monsoon during these months. About one third of the total rainfall in Andhra Pradesh is brought by thenortheast monsoon. October and November see low-pressure systems and tropical cyclones form in the Bay of Bengal which, along with the northeast monsoon, bring rains to the southern and coastal regions of the state. November, December, January, and February are the winter months in Andhra Pradesh. Since the state has a long coastal belt the winters are not very cold. The range of winter temperature is generally 12 C to 30 C.cite webAptdc, Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development Corporationhttp://www.tourisminap.com/know_ap/index.phpAPTDC – Andhra Pradesh Tourism Development CorporationTourisminap.com27 May 201015 August 2010http://web.archive.org/web/20100806000215/http://www.tourisminap.com/know_ap/index.php6 August 2010no

article.heading: Religions
article.paragraph: According to the 2011 census, the Andhra Pradesh state's population (before the state's bifurcation) was around 91.86% Hindu with a Muslim minority of 5.32% along with smaller numbers of Christians, Jains, Sikhs, and Buddhists.

Andhra Pradesh is home to Shankaracharya of Pushpagiri Peetham. Other Hindu saints includeSadasiva Brahmendra,Kannappa NayanarBhaktha Kannappa,Yogi Vemana, YogiSri Potuluri Virabrahmendra Swami, who was born in theVishwabrahmin(goldsmith) caste,cite webhttp://www.mihira.com/wisdommasters/veerabrahmam.htmSri Potuluri Veera Brahmendra SwamiMihira.com29 November 2008http://web.archive.org/web/20081120050546/http://www.mihira.com/wisdommasters/veerabrahmam.htm20 November 2008noSatya Saibaba and many others.Andhra Pradesh has several Hindu shrines. Most important and richest of them isTirumala Tirupati DevasthanamsTirupati Tirumala Devasthanams (TTD).

The Krishna River valley was "a site of extraordinary Buddhist activity for almost a thousand years."Davidson, Ronald.Tibetan Renaissance. Columbia 2005, pp. 29.The ancient Buddhist sites in the lower Krishna Valley, including Amaravati, Nagarjunakonda and Jaggayyapeta "can be traced to at least the third century BCE, if not earlier."Padma, Sree. Barber, Anthony W.Buddhism in the Krishna River Valley of Andhra.SUNY Press 2008, pg. 2.

The region played a central role in the development ofMahayana-buddhism, alongside with theMagadha-erea in northeastern India.Padma, Sree. article.paragraph: The state is divided into two regions viz.,Coastal AndhraandRayalaseema. It has a total of 13 districts, with nine inCoastal Andhraand four inRayalaseema. These 13 districts are further divided into 49 revenue divisions and they are in turn divided into 664mandals.Chittoor districthas the most number ofmandalswith 66 andSrikakulam districthas the least with 37. There are as many as 7 revenue divisions inEast Godavari districtand only 2 inVizianagaram district.cite webPart-I State Administrative Divisions 2001-2011http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011census/maps/atlas/28part1.pdfCensus of India18 January 20156PDF

The districts in the state areAnantapur districtAnantapur,Chittoor districtChittoor,East Godavari districtEast Godavari,Guntur districtGuntur,Kadapa districtKadapa,Krishna districtKrishna,Kurnool districtKurnool,Prakasam districtPrakasam,Nellore districtNellore,Srikakulam districtSrikakulam,Visakhapatnam districtVisakhapatnam,Vizianagaram districtVizianagaramandWest Godavari districtWest Godavari.cite webPopulation of AP districts(2011)http://www.ap.gov.in/districts/ap.gov.in25 May 201414pdf
article.heading: Government and politics
article.paragraph: Legislative Assembly of Andhra Pradeshis the lower house of the state andAndhra Pradesh Legislative Councillegislative council of andhra pradeshis the upper house. with 58 members. In theParliament of India, Andhra Pradesh has 11 seats in theRajya Sabha, and 25 seats in theLok Sabha.cite webhttp://www.apassemblylive.comAndhra Pradesh Legislative AssemblyThere are a total of 175List of Assembly constituencies of Andhra PradeshAssembly constituenciesin the state.East Godavari districthas the most number ofconstituencieswith 19 andVizianagaram districthas the least with 9 assembly seats.cite webDELIMITATION OF PARLIAMENTARY AND ASSEMBLY CONSTITUENCIES ORDER, 2008http://eci.nic.in/eci_main/CurrentElections/CONSOLIDATED_ORDER%20_ECI%20.pdf Election Commission of India11 October 201416–28PDFWhereas, the legislative council of the state has 58 seats, which is one-third of total assembly seats.cite webOverviewhttp://www.aplegislature.org/web/legislative-council/overviewAP LegislatureGovernment of Andhra Pradesh23 May 2015

Until 1962, the CPI, along with socialist parties namelyPraja Socialist Partyand Krishi Lok Party played an important role in the 1950s. In the 1967 state assembly elections, all socialist parties were eliminated andCPIlost opposition party status. The first Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh wasNeelam Sanjiva Reddywho later served as President of India.cite newshttp://www.thehindu.com/news/national/andhra-pradesh/kiran-beats-pv-rosaiah-anjaiah-in-tenure/article4132949.eceThe Hindu, November 25, 201220 December 2013Chennai, India25 November 2012cite newshttp://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article3529044.ece?homepageThe Hindu, on the election and Presidency20 December 2013Chennai, India15 June 2012

In 1983, theTelugu Desam Party(TDP) won the state elections andN.T. Rama Raobecame the chief minister of the state for the first time. This broke the long time single party monopoly enjoyed by the INC from 1956 until 1982.Nandamuri Taraka Rama Raois the founder of Telugu Desam party and served as the first chief minister from the party.cite webhttp://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-telugu-desam-party-turns-29-nt-rama-rao-remembered-1364859Telugu Desam turns 29.20 December 2013The 1989 elections ended the rule ofN. T. Rama RaoNTR, with theIndian National CongressINCparty returning to power withMarri Chenna Reddyat the helm. He was replaced byNedurumalli Janardhana ReddyJanardhan Reddyin 1990, who was replaced byKotla Vijaya Bhaskara Reddyin 1992.

Nara Chandrababu NaiduN. Chandrababu Naiduheld the record for the longest serving chief minister (1995 to 2004).cite webhttp://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/401839/Nara-Chandrababu-NaiduLength of time as Chief Minister20 December 2013In 1994, Andhra Pradesh gave a mandate to theTelugu Desam Partyagain, andN. T. Rama RaoNTRbecame the chief minister again.Nara Chandrababu Naidu, the son-in-law of NTR, came to power with the backing of a majority of theMLAs. The Telugu Desam Party won both the assembly andLok Sabhaelection in 1999 under the leadership ofNara Chandrababu NaiduChandrababu Naidu.

In the ensuing elections the party lost power to a resurgentIndian National CongressINCand its allies andY. S. Rajasekhar Reddybecame theChief Minister.Y. S. Rajasekhar ReddybecameChief Ministeragain by fending off thePraja Rajyam Partyand a major alliance ofTelugu Desam PartyTDP,Telangana Rashtra SamithiTRS,CPIandCommunist Party of India (Marxist)CPM. He died on 2 September 2009 in a helicopter crash.Konijeti Rosaiah, former state finance minister, became the Chief Minister on 3 September 2009, who resigned on 24 November 2010 on the grounds of increased work pressure.Nallari Kiran Kumar Reddywas sworn in as the new Chief Minister, who was also the lastChief Ministerof the united Andhra Pradesh. He resigned after the announcement of the state bifurcation.President's rulewas imposed and the state assembly was dissolved.

In what would be the last elections held in the unified state,Telugu Desam Partygot a mandate in their favor in the residuary (new)state.Nara Chandrababu Naidu, the chief ofTelugu Desam PartybecameChief Ministeron 8 June 2014, for the new state of Andhra Pradesh.cite webCBN to be sworn as CM of Andhra on June 8thhttp://deccan-journal.com/content/cbn-take-oath-june-8thDeccan-Journal2 June 2014
article.heading: Culture
article.paragraph: The early dynasties which ruled this region had their influence on the culture of the state. The state is rich in its culture in terms of religious worships, literature, dance, music, arts and architecture, spicy cuisine. Some of the notable cultural aspects include paintings ofBapu (film director)Bapu,AnnamacharyaAnnamayya'ssongs, famousKuchipudidance of the state, the harvest festivalSankrantiand many more fairs as well.
article.heading: Arts, crafts and artifacts

link.part: Kondapalli Toysat a house in Vijayawada

article.paragraph: The village ofDurgiis known for stone craft, producing carvings ofcult imageidolsin soft stone that must be exhibited in the shade because they are prone to weathering.cite webhttp://guntur.nic.in/durgi_stonecraft.htmlDurgi Stone CraftCesdeva20 December 2013 Kalamkariis an ancient textile art form dating back to theIndus Valley Civilisationand"Srikalahasti" is famous for this art. Andhra Pradesh is famous for doll making. Dolls are made from wood, mud, dry grass, and lightweight metal alloys.Tirupati (city)Tirupatiis famous for redwood carvings.Kondapalliis famous for wood toys with rich colors. The village ofEtikoppaka, located inVisakhapatnam district, produces lacquered toys.

The state has many museums, which features a varied collection of ancient sculptures, paintings, idols, weapons, cutlery and inscriptions, and religious artifacts such as thearchaeological museumatAmaravathi village, Guntur districtAmaravaticite webhttp://asi.nic.in/asi_museums_amravati.aspArchaeological Museum, Amaravati – Archaeological Survey of IndiaAsi.nic.in19 August 2010with features relics of nearby ancient sites,Visakha MuseuminVisakhapatnamdisplays the history of the pre-Independence,cite webhttp://www.vizagcityonline.com/visakha_museum/VizagCityOnline.com — Visakha MuseumVizagcityonline.com29 November 2008http://web.archive.org/web/20081208134038/http://www.vizagcityonline.com/visakha_museum/8 December 2008noand theVictoria Jubilee MuseuminVijayawadawith large a good collection of artifacts.
article.heading: Literature
article.paragraph: MainTelugu literatureNannayya,Tikkana, andYerrapragadaform the trinity who translated the greatSanskritepicMahabharataintoTelugu language.

Nannayya(c. eleventh century AD) was the earliest known poet and translator. He wrote the first treatise on Telugu grammar, called "Andhra Shabda Chintamani" inSanskrit. There was no grammatical work in Telugu prior to that.cite bookA Comparative Study Of Andhrasabdachintamani And BalavyakaranamGopavaramPadmapriyaSubrahmanyam, Korada2011University of HyderabadHyderabad1Pothanais the poet who composed the classicSrimad Maha Bhagavatamu, a Telugu translation ofSri Bhagavatam, authored by Veda Vyasa inSanskrit. The Telugu poetVemana, a native ofKadapa, is notable for his philosophical poems. TheVijayanagaraemperorKrishnadevarayawroteKrishnadevaraya#AmuktamalyadaAmuktamalyada.

Telugu literature afterKandukuri Veeresalingam(18481919) is termed as Adhunika Sahityam (History of modern literatureModern literature). He is known asGadya Tikkanaand was the author ofTelugu languageTelugusocial novel,Satyavati Charitam.Jnanpith Awardwinners includeViswanatha SatyanarayanaSri Viswanatha Satya Narayana. The Andhra Pradesh native and revolutionary poetSrirangam SrinivasaraoSri Sribrought new forms of expressionism into Telugu literature.cite web http://indiaforyou.in/states/andhrapradesh/apculture.phpTelugu Literature8 April 2014Dead linkJuly 2015

Other modern writers includeGunturu Seshendra Sarma(second Nobel prize nominee in literature afterRabindranath Tagore),Puttaparthi Narayanacharyuluwho wrote the booksSivatandavamandPanduranga Mahatyam.Sri Sri (writer)Srirangam Sreenivasarao,Gurram Jashuva,Paravastu ChinnayasuriChinnayasuri,Viswanatha Satyanarayanaare also notable writers.
article.heading: Art forms and festivals
article.paragraph: MainMusic of Andhra PradeshSee alsoShadow Puppets of Andhra PradeshFile:Yamini Reddy kuchipudi.jpgthumbuprightKuchipudi, dance by Yamini ReddyDance:

Classical dance in Andhra can be performed by both men and women; women tend to learn it more often.Kuchipudiis the state's best-known classicaldance forms of Andhra Pradeshdance form. The various classical dance forms (astriya Nrutyam) such asKuchipudi,Andhra Natyam,Bhamakalapam,Veeranatyamand folk dances(Janapada Nrutyam) forms such as Butta bommalu, Tappeta Gullu,Lambadi, Dhimsa, and Chindu exists in Andhra Pradesh.

Jayapa Senani was the first person to write about the dances prevalent in Andhra Pradesh.cite webhttp://www.telugupeople.com/discussion/article.asp?id''Ntitya Ratnavali''Both Desi and Margi forms of dances are included in his Sanskrit treatiseNrutya Ratnavali.
File:Balamuralikrishna in Kuwait.jpgthumbBalamuralikrishnaduring a concert in Kuwait on 29 March 2006Music:

Many composers ofCarnatic musiclikeAnnamacharya,Tyagaraja,Kshetrayya, andBhadrachala Ramadaswere of Telugu descent. Modern Carnatic music composers likeGhantasala (singer)GhantasalaandM. Balamuralikrishnaare also of Telugu descent. The Telugu film industry hosts many music composers and playback singers such asS. P. Balasubrahmanyam,P. Susheela,S. Janaki,P B Srinivas. Folk songs are popular in the many rural areas of the state. Forms such as theBurra kathaandPoliare still performed today.cite bookMusical Heritage of IndiaManorma Sharma19–322007APH81-313-0046-3
Harikatha:

Harikathaa Kalakshepam (or Harikatha)involves the narration of a story, intermingled with various songs relating to the story. Harikatha was originated in Andhra.cite bookThoomati DonappaTelugu Harikatha Sarvasvam13505520Harikatha Kalakshepam is most prevalent in Andhra Pradesh even now along withBurra katha.Haridasusgoing round villages singing devotional songs is an age-old tradition during Dhanurmaasam precedingSankrantifestival.Ajjada Adibhatla Narayana Dasuwith his Kavyas and Prabandhas has made Harikatha a special art form.
Burra katha:

Burra katha is aoral storytellingtechnique in theKatha (storytelling format)Kathatradition, performed in villages ofTelanganaand coastal Andhra Pradesh region. The troupe consists of one main performer and two co-performers. It is a narrative entertainment that consists of prayers, solo drama, dance, songs, poems and jokes. The topic will be either aHindumythological story or a contemporary social issue.cite webBurrakatha loses sheen sans patronagehttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/visakhapatnam/Burrakatha-loses-sheen-sans-patronage/articleshow/18012802.cms?referralJan 14, 20132013-09-02 [[The Times of India]]
Festivals:

Ugadiis celebrated as theTelugu New Year. People listen toPanchangarecitals by Pundits on the day of Ugadi. This process is called asPanchanga Shravanamwhich is an important aspect of the festival.Makara Sankrantiis also a famous harvest festival which is celebrated across the state. Just like in other parts of the country, many other festivals includeVijayadashamiDasara,Ganesh ChaturthiVinayaka Chaviti,DiwaliDeepavali,HoliVasantotsavam,Maha Shivaratri, Attla Taddi etc. Muslim festivals includeBakrid,Ramadanand Christians celebrateChristmasandEaster.
article.heading: Cuisine
article.paragraph: File:Vegetarian Andhra Meal.jpg240pxthumbrightA Vegetarian Andhra Meal served on important occasionsCuisine of Andhra Pradesh is famous for the rich seasoning and lots of variety.Riceis thestaple foodand is used in a wide variety of dishes. Typical meal includes rice,Lentilspappu (dal), vegetable curry,relishes, pickles, chutneys andcurd. A lot of spices are produced in the region and hence the cuisine of Andhra Pradesh is considered spiciest of all.Tamarindandred chilliesare the distinct flavor of local cuisine.

Indian picklePicklesand chutneys (sauces) are made from chilli,ginger,coconutand other vegetables liketomato,Eggplantbrinjals,roselle (plant)gonguraare served with meals.Mango pickleAavakaayais probably the best known of the pickles.cite webhttp://www.indianfoodforever.com/andhra/Andhra Food3 April 2014Roselle (plant)Roselleleaves (gongura), termed asAndhra bhakshyam(or food of Andhra).Rayalaseemaregion too had its own variety which includesSorghum bicolorjonna(jowar),Finger milletragirotiwithFinger milletragisangati, usually served withspinach.

The coastal region of the state has abundant seafood supply. The variety of fish curry recipes are famous. It is rich and aromatic, with a liberal use of exotic spices and ghee (clarified butter). Lamb, chicken are also the most widely used meats in the non-vegetarian dishes.cite webhttp://www.indianfoodforever.com/andhra/Non-vegetarian dishes3 April 2014

Sweets made up of milk are widely eaten.KheerPayasamis one of them made with milk, rice or vermicelli pudding served both warm and cold.Pootharekulu,Puran Polibobbattlu,Aam papadmamidi tandra,Kakinada khajakaja,ariselu(rice based vada using jaggery) etc., are famous sweets.
article.heading: Economy

link.part: Visakhapatnamis an important commercial hub of the state

article.paragraph: Andhra Pradesh has a very diverse geography which led to a very diverse economy. As many as 9 of the 13 districts have sea coast along theBay of Bengal, which has created manufacturing and export centric industry. The fertile river plains in the delta regions of major peninsular rivers of Godavari and Krishna are rich with agriculture-based industries and the mineral deposits found in the districts of Rayalaseema, Eastern Ghats and neighboring states has led to large-scale ore exports.

The gross state domestic product (GSDP) of Andhra Pradesh wasINRConvert2359.3bonin 201213. The domestic product of agriculture sector accounts forINRConvert545.99bonand Industrial sector forINRConvert507.45bon. The service sector of the state accounts more percentage of the GSDP with a total ofINRConvert1305.87bon.cite webEconomyhttp://www.ap.gov.in/AP%20State%20Statistical%20Abstract%20May%202014/4_AP_Economy.pdfOfficial portal of Andhra Pradesh GovernmentAP state portal21 June 2014PDFIn the 2010 list byForbesmagazine, there were several from Andhra Pradesh among the top 100 richest Indians.cite newshttp://www.forbes.com/lists/2010/77/india-rich-10_Indias-Richest_Rank.htmlIndia's RichestForbes.com29 September 201031 January 2014
article.heading: Agriculture

link.part: Lush green farms inKonaseema,East Godavari districtEast Godavari

article.paragraph: With an economy mainly based on agriculture and livestock, Andhra Pradesh is an exporter of many agricultural products and is also known as "Rice Bowl of India".cite newsAppaji ReddemRice bowl of Indiahttp://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/rice-bowl-of-india-worst-hit/article5227645.ece7 June 2014The Hinducite bookIndia TodayABC-CLIO978-0-313-37462-336https://books.google.co.in/books?id15 November 2014Four important rivers of India, theGodavari RiverGodavari,Krishna RiverKrishna,Penner RiverPenna, andTungabhadra RiverThungabhadra, flow through the state and provide irrigation. Agriculture is the main occupation and 60 percent of population is engaged in agriculture and related activities. Rice is the major food crop and staple food of the state.

Besides rice, farmers also grow wheat, jowar, bajra, maize, minor millet, coarse grain, many varieties of pulses, oil seeds,sugarcane,cotton,chili pepper,mangonuts and tobacco. Crops used for vegetable oil production such assunflowerand peanuts are popular. There are many multi-state irrigation projects under development, includingGodavari River Basin Irrigation ProjectsandNagarjuna Sagar Dam.cite webIrrigation Projectshttp://www.pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relidPress Information BureauMinistry of Water Resources2014-06-09

Livestock and poultry is also another profitable business, which involves rearing cattle in enclosed areas for commercial purposes. The state is also a largest producer of eggs in the country and hence, it is nicknamed as "Egg Bowl of Asia".cite webSocio Economic Survey 2013-14http://www.ap.gov.in/Other%20Docs/Socio%20Economic%20Survey%20Book%20let.pdfAP State PortalGovernment of Andhra Pradesh27 June 20153PDFcite bookMohantyMuktikantaMacmillan's General Knowledge Manual 20102010Macmillan978-0-230-32874-772https://books.google.co.in/books?id15 November 2014

Fisheries contribute 10% of total fish and over 70% of the shrimp productioncite webhttp://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-andhrapradesh/ap-top-producer-of-shrimp-mpeda/article4311671.eceAP top producer of shrimp: MPEDASpecial CorrespondentThe Hinduof India. The geographical location of the state allows marine fishing as well as inland fish production. The most exported marine exports includeWhiteleg shrimpVannamei shrimpcite webVannamei Hatcherieshttp://www.caa.gov.in/Coastal Aquaculture Authority16 July 2014yeshttps://web.archive.org/20140603143059/http://www.caa.gov.in/3 June 2014and are expected to cross $1 billion in 2013-14.cite webhttp://viscan.in/?pThe $ Billion Andhra Shrimp exportsviscan.in
article.heading: Industrial sector

article.paragraph: The industrial sector of the state include some of the key sectors likePharma industryPharma,Automobile industryAutomobile,Textile industry in IndiaTextilesetc.Sricitylocated inNellore districtis an integrated business city which is home to many renowned firms likePepsiCo,Isuzu Motors,Cadbury India,Kellogg's,Colgate-Palmolive,Kobelcoetc.cite webFirms in sricityhttp://www.sricity.in/customer.htmlSricity.in14 May 2015ThePepsiCofirm has its largest plant inIndiaat Sri City.cite webV Rishi KumarPepsiCo inaugurates new facility at Sri Cityhttp://www.thehindubusinessline.com/companies/pepsico-to-commission-new-unit-at-sri-city-today/article7064372.eceThe Hindu Business Line14 May 2015Hyderabad3 April 2015

The state is also emerging in information technology and biotechnology. The IT/ITES revenues of theVisakhapatnamalone is atINRConvert14.45bin 201213. The development of IT in Tier-II and Tier-III cities likeVijayawada,KakinadaandTirupati, Andhra PradeshTirupatiare also improving. In the fiscal year 201213, Vijayawada's IT/ITeS revenues wereINRConvert1152.6mcrore whileTirupati, Andhra PradeshTirupatiwithINRConvert693mandKakinadawithINRConvert615.4m.cite webIT/ITES revenueshttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/visakhapatnam/Visakhapatnam-IT/ITeS-sector-surges-20-in-2013/articleshow/22592960.cmsTimes of India6 June 2014Other include .
article.heading: Resources
article.paragraph: Andhra Pradesh is one of the storehouses of mineral resources inIndia. Andhra Pradesh with varied geological formations, contain rich and variety of industrial minerals and building stones.cite webIndustrial & Fertilizer mineralshttp://www.portal.gsi.gov.in/gsiDoc/pub/peer_reviewed_base_document_com_iv.pdfGeological Survey of India portalCGPB Committee-IV17–44PDF2014-06-09

Andhra Pradesh is listed top in the deposit and production of mica in India. Minerals found in the state include limestone, reserves of oil and natural gas, manganese, asbestos, iron ore, ball clay, fire clay, gold diamonds, graphite, dolomite, quartz, tungsten, steatitic, feldspar, silica sand. It has about one third of India'slimestonereserves and is known for large exclusive deposits of barytes and galaxy granite in the international market.

Miningis identified as one of the growth engines for the overall development of industry and infrastructure. TheTummalapalle Uranium minein Andhra has confirmed 49,000 tonnes of ore and there are indications that it could hold reserves totaling three times its current size. 700 million tonnes of metal grade Bauxite deposits in close proximity toVisakhapatnam Port.

Reliance Industries Limited struck nine trillion cubic feet of gas reserves in theKrishna Godavari Basin,convert150kmmionoff the Andhra Pradesh coast nearKakinada. Discovery of large quantity of natural gas in KG Basin is expected to provide rapid economic growth.cite webKrishna Godavari Basin: Oil & Gas Resourcehttp://www.kgbasin.in/kgbasin.in7 June 2014

There are both thermal and hydel power plants.Natural gas, one of the cheapest source in power generation is in abundance.cite newsNatural Gas in Krishna-Godavari basinhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Andhra-Pradesh-to-get-additional-gas/articleshow/23430327.cms?referral20 December 2013Times of India3 Oct 2013APGENCOis the power generating organization of Andhra Pradesh.cite webhttp://www.apgenco.gov.in/home.doAPGENGO overview19 June 2014APGENCOoverviewThermal power plantswith total capacity of 5610 MegawattMWare situated in the state which includesDr Narla Tata Rao Thermal Power Station(1760 MegawattMW),Rayalaseema Thermal Power Station(1050 MegawattMW),Sri Damodaram Sanjeevaiah Thermal Power Station(800 MegawattMW) are ofAPGENCO,Simhadri Super Thermal Power Plant(2000 MegawattMW) ofNTPC LimitedNTPC, and the Hydel power plants are having a capacity of 3693.20 MegawattMW. There are also nonconventional power generation plants contributing a small portion to the power generation in the state.cite webAPGENCO projectshttp://www.apgenco.gov.in/getInfo.doAndhra Pradesh Power Generation Corporation3 June 2014
article.heading: Transportation
article.paragraph: The state is well connected to other states through road and rail networks. It is also connected to other countries by means of airways and seaports as well. With a long seacoast along theBay of Bengal, it also has many ports for sea trade. The state has one of the largest railway junctions at Vijayawada and one of the largest seaports at Visakhapatnam.
article.heading: Roads
article.paragraph: See alsoAPSRTCFile:NH5 Ongole.jpgthumbnailNational Highway 5 (India)National Highway 5nearOngoleFile:Garuda Plus - Mercedes Benz - A.jpgthumbleftGaruda Plus bus service of theAPSRTCFile:Vijayawada varadhi.jpgthumbnailVaradhi bridge way toVijayawadaandGunturRoads in Andhra Pradesh consist ofNational Highway (India)National Highwaysand state highways with district roads as well.National Highway 5 (India)(old numbering)NH 5, with a highway network of aroundconvert1000kmmionin the state, is a part ofGolden Quadrilateral Projectundertaken byNational Highways Development Project. It also forms part ofAsian HighwayAH 45which comes under theAsian Highway Network.

TheAndhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation(APSRTC) is the major public bus transport owned by the state government which runs thousands of buses connecting different parts of the state.Pandit Nehru Bus Station(PNBS) inVijayawadais one of the largest bus terminals inAsia.cite webhttp://www.apsrtc.gov.in/Contact%20Us/Grievances/Citi-Chart.htmciti-CharterApsrtc.gov.in19 August 2010http://web.archive.org/web/20100917143549/http://apsrtc.gov.in/Contact%20Us/Grievances/Citi-Chart.htm17 September 2010no
article.heading: Railways
article.paragraph: Andhra Pradesh has a railway network ofconvert5046kmmionand have played a significant role in boosting the economy of the state alongside developing the industrial and the tourism sectors. One of the highest broad gauge tracks in the world is in Eastern Ghats route that runs fromVisakhapatnamto Anantagiri.cite webhttp://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/andhrapradesh/andhrapradeshrailways.htmRail Network2 April 2014Most of Andhra Pradesh falls under withGuntur railway divisionGuntur,Vijayawada railway divisionVijayawada,Guntakal railway divisionGuntakal(South Central Railway zoneand Waltair (East Coast Railway zone) divisions. This serves the north coastal districts.

Waltair Railway DivisionunderEast Coast Railway zoneECoR zone, is fourth largest revenue earning division inIndia.cite newsWaltair division earningshttp://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Visakhapatnam/waltair-division-records-alltime-high-earnings/article3299428.ece9 June 2014The Hindu10 April 2012Vijayawada railway stationis the highest grosser in theSouth Central Railway zoneSCR zoneand one of busiest railway junctions inIndia.
article.heading: Airports
